clinical_study.brief_title: Evaluation of the Efficacy of Non-drug Therapy (SMS Intervention) for Children and Adolescents With Repeated NSSI
clinical_study.official_title: Evaluation of the Efficacy of Non-drug Therapy (SMS Intervention) for Children and Adolescents With Repeated NSSI

brief_summary.textblock: In this proposed study,Text messages are used to intervene in the repeated NSSI behavior of children and adolescents, and the efficacy of this intervention method is evaluated, as well as the internal mechanism of children and adolescents' repeated NSSI behavior is discussed.

detailed_description.textblock: In this proposed study, the investigators will evaluate the effect of text message intervention on repeated self-injury behavior intervention in children and adolescents. The study will recruit 110 cases of children and adolescents with depression and bipolar disorder in outpatient and ward, then these patient will be randomized to the intervention group (55 cases) or the control group (55 cases) for three month clinnic trial. Clinical efficacy and safety assessment will be done at baseline, fourteen week and twenty-six week. The specific aims are to evaluate the effect of text message intervention on repeated NSSI in children and adolescentsare on: 1) self-injury behavior; 2) suicidal behavior; 3)suicidal tendency and NSSI tendency. and the behavior was evaluated by NSSI scale and Beck Suicide Scale.

primary_outcome.measure: The change of NSSI behavior of children and adolescents with NSSI
primary_outcome.description: NSSI are measured by Self-injury scale

primary_outcome.measure: The change of suicide behavior of children and adolescents with NSSI
primary_outcome.description: Suicide behavior are measured by The Baker Suicidal ideation Questionnaire

arm_group.description: Text messages will be sent to the subjects through the system, including reminding the patients to take medicine on time, returning to the hospital regularly, and giving popularization of psychiatric knowledge and coping skills.Three times a week for three months.
Subjects also collected in the outpatient department and the ward were randomly divided into the control group and regularly followed up.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Adolescents aged 12-17 years old,
2. normal intelligence,
3. able to complete all examinations and interventions,
4. had two or more nsSI behaviors in the past 6 months,
5. the guardian agrees to fill in the informed consent form.
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Severe neurological and organic diseases, severe mental disorders and eating disorders;
2. Patients with severe suicidal behavior;
3. Patients who cannot complete the examination and intervention measures;
4. Patients and guardians are reluctant to participate.
